Rooms are great, ask for a canal or garden view on lower levels as top floor rooms tend to be hard to get to. Great location and within walking distance to everything and many great sites and restaurants close. A bit pricey but worth it. I highly and do recommend the Hotel Pulitzer, A Luxury Collection/Starwood Collection. I will be staying at Hotel Pulitzer on a regular basis with trips to Amsterdam.

reviews.text: The hotel seemed pretty nice in the public area as we checked in. But as people who visited this property would agree, the halls are mazes. Once out of the elevator, you have to go up and down in these small stairs to get to your room. We were only there for a night so it was alright but if you are staying for a week or so, I think it would defintely get annoying. Also, it's much much harder to go through these halls with luggage! You defintely need a bellman unless you only have one small bag like I did.

Our room was quite impressive. Because the elevator goes upto 5th floor, I thought we had one more floor above us. Yet this was quickly learned wrong as I entered the room. Our room had incredibly high valted ceiling! From the look of it, I'm guessing it had a attic above that was opened up when they converted it to a hotel. The high ceiling gave a feel of more space to the already spacious room. And the view! We were directly looking out to the canal with nice old charm windows. It was wonderful to sit near the window in the chairs or bed and look out at the canal. We were so tired from the trip but even if not, I'd be glad to spend time in the room we had. It was a nice experience from modern city hotels we were used to in US.

reviews.title: Canalside Treat
reviews.text: We found a (relatively) great rate for the Pulitzer on Sheraton's website. The Prinsengracht property boasts a prime location for those who want a taste of romantic Amsterdam and is in easy walking distance of all museums and attractions. This is really where you want to stay in Amsterdam -- away from the Dam Square's touristy hubub and in the midst of residential high-life. Our room in the gable of a canal house was perfectly charming. The heated marble bathroom floor was truly luxurious. Try to get a room with a a canal view.

I've stayed at the Pulitzer 3 - 4 times now in the last 6 months, and it's been a wonderful experience each time. The only reason I don't rate it as excellent is that the size of the rooms is extremely variable, with some boasting romantic views of the canal, and others pokey views of back walls. That said, every room has character, and has been spotlessly clean and well appointed. By Dutch standards, the service is very friendly and helpful, and the hotel remains an oasis in a desert of mediocre, standardised business hotels. If you're visiting Amsterdam as a (romantic) tourist, try to get a canal facing room - unless you like to sleep with the window open...
reviews.title: Good for business & for pleasure

reviews.text: I had some reservations about booking with the Pulitzer after reading the mixed reviews but was talked into it by my travel agent who books high end travel. I must say it is in a good location and one of the nicer hotels in Amsterdam. The bathrooms are small but like every one else said are nicely done and meet all the needs. Both the rooms I stayed in were well appointed and fine for a nice holiday room. However, we did have several issues. We were woken up by a mouse scratching at the door trying to get out of our room. Needless to say we were immediately moved to an upgraded room with a view of the canals only to find out the mini bar was broken and never able to be fixed during our stay. Also the mini bar is electronic and make mistakes at the slightest jiggle The buffet breakfast was included with our package but would have been 25 euro each if not included- which is way too high.

reviews.text: We stayed at the Pulitzer at the end of a family trip to Europe from 26 July to 29 July 2006. From our greeting by the doorman to the friendly assistance we received at the desk, our check in was a breeze. Unfortunately, on the internet I had booked two of the wrong types of rooms for our family of two adults and three teenagers, but not only did the desk person find a combination of rooms that suited our needs, but she upgraded us as well, at no additional charge. The Pulitzer is old, quirky, and charming. There were exposed beams in our canal-view room. If you want the feeling of staying in a well-maintained, clean, Amsterdam-style home in a quiet neighborhood, the Pulitzer is for you.

reviews.title: Repeat visit a bit disappointing, but still has charm
reviews.text: We just got back from a stay at the Pulitzer September 21-24, 04. We had stayed there in 2001 and loved our room, which overlooked the Prinsengracht Canal. We booked the same room. I had several emails with the hotel reservation agent and I guaranteed the room with my credit card. When we arrived, the reservation clerk insisted we had not guaranteed the reservation and our room was no longer available and the hotel was overbooked. I insisted that I had guaranteed the room with my credit card and she did give us a room that overlooked the same canal, but was in a different building and wasn't as nice as the room we had reserved. I called the reservation agent the next morning and she offered us a different room, but it was no nicer than the one we were in, so we declined. They did nothing to compensate, such as offer us a free breakfast at least, which I thought would have been appropriate. We were a bit disappointed, but still, the hotel is very nice, and the location is great. The bed was very comfortable, the amenities are great, the heated marble floors in the bathrooms are a nice touch, especially in chilly Amsterdam. The Joordan area is the best for nice walks, unusual shops and galleries and good restaurants. The hotel breakfast is hugely overpriced, but there are lots of nice little places for breakfast in the immediate area. Amsterdam is a great city and I would definitely go back and I might give the Pulitzer antother chance when I do.

We used our Sheraton points for our entire stay and upgraded from the initial room given us which was very tiny and a little shabby. It was only 40E more a night to get a large room that was quite nice. The staff was very accommodating in helping us and showed us three rooms to pick from.

reviews.text: We stayed at the Pulitzer for a couple of nights. The hotel is in a great location in Jordaan and sits between 2 canals. Staff are very helpful and friendly. If the weather is good, there is a peaceful garden at the centre of the hotel. However, parts of the hotel are really on the shabby side, particularly some of the common areas byond the lobby - not what you'd expect of a 5 star hotel; and you can't help feeling they could create a bit more character out of the very promising start of a set of canal houses. Our room, though well-appointed and with views of the canal, was on the small side and did not justify the cost. All in all, a safe hotel but lacking in the touches and details that you'd expect at the price, hence the average rating.

reviews.title: Loved the Pulitzer
reviews.text: Stayed at the Pulitzer for 3 nights, the first week in September - very nice hotel - our room was a little small, but very well appointed - I had requested a garden view room which was granted - no view but the room was very quiet - the location of the hotel is perfect as it's in an upmarket residential area of Amsterdam - close to restaurants and cafe's and a short walk to Dam Square - don't bother with breakfast at the hotel - there are plenty of small cafe's with great breakfasts, close by for a fraction of the price

reviews.title: Luxury with a smile
reviews.text: A touch of luxury but delivered with good humour and without the 'stuffiness' you might expect from such a renowned hotel group. Great location in one of the prettiest parts of Amsterdam, surrounded by excellent restaurants and bars. The room was spacious and beautifully furnished. Breakfast was a real event and all the staff were extremely friendly and helpful. We would have no hesitation in returning to the Pulitzer or in recommending this great Hotel to others.

reviews.title: Pulitzer Hotel WOW!
reviews.text: The Hotel Pulitzer for Queen's Day was the best experience imaginable!! The Hotel is exquisite, clean and the staff is not be be beat. OUr room overlooked the canal and were were able to see the parade of boats on the water from our double wide windows. It is a Sheridan, but you would never know it. Very European and unlike a chain. We were there for Queen's day (Like USA's Fourth of July and Mardi Gras combined). Everyone was well-behaved and partying. It was a blast. The Museams are awesome (Van Gogh, Rikjsmuseam, etc.) The Heineken Experience was just OK. The best was the Kuenenhoff Gardens in Lisse. The tuplips were in bloom, along with agazilion other beautiful bulbs. Meticulous grounds that would take your breath away. The trams are fun and easy to take around the city. The trains are clean, fast and safe to take you to Lisse and the Hague. People are sweet and friendly. PLUS, they were filming"Oceans 12" at the Pulitzer with Brad Pitt and George Clooney. What else can I say? Go. Go, now!!

reviews.title: A lovely hotel in a brilliant location
reviews.text: A lovely, luxurious hotel. We got a good deal on Expedia and when we were there we upgraded to a superior room. We had lovely views of the Prinsengracht from our three huge windows. The room was very comfortable with a massive bed and a gleaming bathroom. The staff were very smiley and approachable. Just a shame they don't throw a continental breakfast in for the price. If they had I would have given full marks.

This hotel is constructed from a number of connected canal houses, so the room tend to be small, but nicely appointed. The staff all speak perfect English and are nothing but helpful. The biggest perk may be the location which is on a main canal just down from the Anne Frank House. This puts you within walking distance of everything in Amsterdam. The biggest downside is the price, which tends to be in excess of €200 per night.
reviews.title: Nice Place, Great Location, Great Staff

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If you can swing it, this is a nice place with a great location.
reviews.title: Deeply disappointing

likes.liked: — That we were only staying for one night

reviews.text: Having booked a deluxe room at the Pulitzer, we were very much looking forward to our one night stay. However, from the moment that we had to walk through a series of corridors that got darker and more tatty the further we went, our expectations were disappointed. Finally, having lugged our suitcases up a winding and dirty staircase we got to our room. It was small and smelt very strongly of smoke. When booking, I had ticked the non-smoking preference and neither of us felt comfortable in such a smoky atmosphere. When my husband returned to reception to ask if we could change rooms, he was told we had requested a smoking room, which was untrue. The woman at front desk was unprepared to do anything to rectify the hotel's mistake other than to offer to have some air fresheners sent to the room. We were extremely unimpressed by the quality of service we encountered. Further, there was damp on the wall behind our bed, the view was of ugly air conditioning units and the bathroom was so small that you couldn't stand up to use the toilet. The high price we paid to stay here does not represent value for money as far as we are concerned and we would choose to stay at an alternative hotel in Amsterdam in future.
reviews.title: Fabulous hotel!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I stayed at the hotel during my first trip to Amsterdam. I was greated warmly and checked in with ease. As a SPG I was updated to a wonderful room at the end of the hallway. ALthough it wasn't a huge room by any means it was big enough for me. I did have some troubles with the in room internet connection but these were fixed by the second day. The bathroom was well appointed although the only disappointment was that the tub stopper didn't work so my luxurious soak was cut short. The hotel area is wonderful -you should definitely check out the Anne Frank house. I took a nice stroll one evening and enjoyed the canal views.
reviews.title: Great Hotel - with a few flaws

likes.liked: — The quality and location of room

likes.liked: — The atmosphere and location. Although it 's a big hotel, it felt like a boutique hotel with courtyards and hallways like a comfortable, interesting maze.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I visited Amsterdam and decided to stay in this Starwood Luxury Collection Hotel. Although the hotel appears to be one building it is actually a combination of many different buildings nested together to form the hotel. The first room we were given appeared to have someone else staying in it so we were given another room that just so happened to be an upgraded room. The staff was friendly and appologized for the mix of with the rooms. We enjoyed the high cealings and the large size of the room for a hotel in Europe. One of the best parts of staying in this hotel was its close proximity to everything we wanted to see from the Anne Frank House to our bike tour of the city to the Van Gogh museum. If we visit the city again we would definately stay here.
reviews.title: Great Location To Major Sites

I can only echo the review of Trip Adviser Member NY. My partner and I recently stayed at The Pulitzer. This is definately not a 5 Star Hotel. It is overrun with rodents. On check out we had to ask for a refund on the first nights stay we were then offered a 30% discount.

reviews.text: The Hotel Pulitzer is comprised of several former homes on one big block to form a bigger hotel. The hotel is filled with charm, but it can be quite a process winding your way up and down the hallways, to find your room, due to the pathways that connect the former homes.
reviews.title: Very pleasant hotel, and great location

reviews.text: The standard rooms are very nice. They're the quaint size of the average NYC hotel, and not the room size of some of the bigger hotels in the middle of America. I chose a garrden room, only because I wanted quiet, and I did not know how much noise there might be near the canal.
reviews.title: Imperfections Forgiven --- We Had a Very Pleasant Stay

reviews.text: The queen size bed I had was split right down the middle with two separate duvet white comforters on top of the queen bed, so that two people could each have their own blanket for their own "side." It was somewhat annoying, as the blanket for your side is small. But the room is very clean, and very up to date. BOSE speakers next to your bed, nice lighting, and hardwood floors. There is turndown service, great bathrobes, slippers, chocolate by your bedside.
reviews.title: Fab Hotel
Nice Hotel
reviews.text: The bathroom is also clean and sophisticated, but small. The marble floor is heated! There is a mini-bar with motion sensors, so don't take anything out if you don't want to be charged.

reviews.title: This is the place to stay
reviews.text: The concierge of the hotel is hit or miss. Some of the staff is very courteous, others are somewhat stuck up. They did recommend buying a ticket in advance to Van gogh Museum, and I was able to buy it there. Great advice, because the museum is mobbed with ticket buyers. There is usually a wait to get help at the concierge desk.

reviews.title: Great hotel in Amsterdam
reviews.text: We stayed in room 503 at this very nice hotel. The staff was attentive (though the concierge could be a bit gruff), and the breakfasts were out of this world! Be sure to get a rate that include breakfast - it will keep you going all day! The rooms that end in -03, are in an old warehouse building and are so cool! Brick walls, hardwood floors, windows that open on to the canal. They are executive rooms, but are worth the money and worth asking for that specially. Room 502 is interior, but also charming. We loved the local of this hotel, easy walk to most everything but away from the craziness. You can be crazy and come home to quiet!

I stayed at the Pulitzer on July 16th, 2005. This was my second stay at the hotel. Overall, I like this place. I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for an upscale place to stay in the heart of Amsterdam. I will try to organize my thoughts below in terms of PLUS (things I like) and MINUS (things I did not like) about the Pulitzer.
reviews.title: Upscale Place To Stay

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I stayed at the Pulitzer the first week of May. It has a great location, right on the canals, and the attention to detail in the furnishings is evident. The courtyards are very nice too. But I don't think the hotel provides the service level, especially the concierge's desk, to justify the high room rates they charge and a 5 star rating. For example, I emailed the concierge 3 days before my arrival and listed several restaurants I was interested in dining at. I said I was totally flexible regarding which night where. When I checked in, nothing had been done regarding dinner reservations. One of the concierges also seemed irritated at times when I was asking questions about transportation and specific recommendations for tourist activities on any given day. And one of the concierges didn't have a very strong command of English. A 5 star hotel concierge desk would have been all over dinner reservations, the individuals working there would all be extremely fluent in English and their attitude would be totally focused on customer satisfaction. So great hotel from an aesthetic perspective, great location, just not the best value for the price.
reviews.title: Very nice, but not a 5 star

reviews.text: We have stayed here 3 times in the last 4 years. As platinum Starwood members we were upgraded on this trip to a suite. The suite was a 2 story apartment: foyer, kitchenette, 1 bathroom, 2 bedrooms and living area. The architecture was fantastic: beamed ceilings, glasswalls - very quaint. It overlooked the canal. There were 2 adults and 3 children and it was perfect.
reviews.title: A special hotel

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The architecture inside and out is beautiful. We find it very appealing. The only difficult part is sometimes finding your way to your room with all of the turns and steps, etc.
reviews.title: The best in Amsterdam!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The service as always is so personal, friendly and helpful. The breakfast buffet has the typical European fare along with some American favorites. The bar is also very relaxing with outstanding service and ambience.
reviews.title: Fantastic location

reviews.text: The location is great for sightseeing. You are very close to the Anne Frank House, Dam Square, Jordaan neighborhood, flower market, and tram stops. We also walked to Centraal Station, Rijksmuseum, VanGogh museum, Leidesplain, etc.
reviews.title: Beautiful hotel on canal

likes.disliked: — Would not be good for travelers with disabilities due to steps through warren of connecting townhouses.

reviews.text: I currently work in Amsterdam and tried many hotels between January and February whilst I was waiting for my apartment to be ready. We stayed in the Pulitzer during bad weather as we were unable to travel home due to storms...
reviews.title: Just OK... but fabulous for breakfast!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Pulitzer is just OK - no more and no less. It's a beautiful location and has fantasic canal views. The rooms are all different - and some of them are quite odd sizes as they have been fitted into the old houses. The beds are comfy, the bathrooms nice (not all have bath tubs), nice products and the decor good general standard. It just doesn't stand up to the hype or to the price they charge.
reviews.title: Terrible value for money

reviews.text: I would, however, really recommend visiting the Pulitzer for breakfast... it is an excellent buffet in a bright sunny room... love it and always take all my vistors to Amsterdam there.

reviews.title: Excellent, No Negatives

reviews.text: I have just returned from the Pulitzer and our stay was amazing. We were greated by a smilling doorman who carried our bags in and check-in took only minutes. We were upgraded to a delux room which was huge - big enough for an extra bed for our nine-year-old. The bath room was large with a tub - nicely furnished with marble in subtle colours.
reviews.title: Fantastic

reviews.text: My wife and I stayed at the Pulitzer for two nights. We arrived at 1400 and were immediately assigned a very nice room with a king bed overlooking the Garden Area as I had requested. The room was very large for a European Hotel with a very high ceiling. As is known, this Hotel is a collection of canal houses so the path to the Room was somewhat involved but easy to remember.

If I had been on vacation and/or paying for this myself, I would have either demanded another room, or left the Pulitzer and stayed at one of the many bed and breakfasts in the area at half the price.

reviews.text: Room was small and very efficient. Nice view from the 3rd floor of the back of the building, a large courtyard with trees, flowers, and little cafe tables. Bathroom was great, one of the nicest showers (comfort, pressure, temperature) that I've used in Europe. The bed was the standard (seemingly) of most European hotels, with a comforter for a sheet, and a little lower to the ground than USA beds. They had the "pick your pillow" option, where you can get a different pillow if you'd like, but I was fine with the one's provided. The room had an internet drop, 20 euros for a 24 hour pretty fast connection.
reviews.title: Way Behind the Times/Poore Service

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: It's about a 10-15 minute walk to the park in the center of Amsterdam, where the Picasso museum is. It's about a 30 second walk to the Anne Frank house.
reviews.title: We loved this hotel

reviews.text: When checking out, I was still thinking the hotel was nice but a bit over my budget, seeing the bill with restaurant charges and taxes. However, something nice happened as we grabbed our bags to leave. One of the clerks approached me and told me I had left something in the room, so wait a little until it gets send down. At first, I thought it was probably nothing important but what do you know? When he handed me the left "item," the hotel suddenly seemed such a good value. It was my travel companion's wallet, filled with dollars, euros, pounds, credit cards, and last but the most important, her Green Card. We passed a housekeeping staff as we left the room and I guess he picked it up when he went to clean our room. Besides losing money, we would have a lot more than a problem coming back home without my friend's green card. And the annoying process of cancelling credit cards! We really appreciated the housekeeping staff and front desk clerk rushing to get to us before we left.
reviews.title: Another Great Experince
Not happy
reviews.text: The entrance is nice, staff seemed welcoming and the view over the canal was lovely (room 280). The room has beautiful furniture and it's charming by traditional European standards. Now the problems are: my bed sagged, so it was uncomfortable for two people to sleep together, furniture and bathroom seem to be cramped in little space, the corridors are somewhat laberinthic, there is some AC or pipe noises in the room at night. Breakfast is OK.
This hotel is in a great location for exploring Amsterdam on foot.
reviews.title: Great location, but not a deluxe 5 star!
Will go back any time
reviews.text: My husband and I spent 3 nights at the Pulitzer in an executive room. The first room we were given had someone else in it! It looked very small and dark so we were quite glad we had the chance to get another room. We had a canal view room that was reasonably spacious although the bathroom was on the small side. We had no problems with noise (we were on the 4th floor) and housekeeping did an adequate job.
Breakfast was included in our rate and was well worth it. Breakfast does not finish until 2.30 pm at the weekend so you could have this as a brunch and set yourself up for the day.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The hotel is good in many ways, it's just that I can't rave about it. The location is great, the staff were all polite & attentive, the bed (& sheets) were fabulous (reminded me of my previous trip to the Westin in New York), the breakfast was wide-ranging & plentiful. It's probably the room itself that lets down the hotel. It was quaint but also a little tired. Exposed beams add the quirkiness but the dust sat on top is a bit of a letdown. The bathroom was clumsily designed in the corner of the room & the crack in the basin & mouldy grout in the bath/shower should be attended to. One man's "luxury" is another man's "okay". My previous stay at the Urban in Madrid is poles apart from this property. That was modern, chic & new. This hotel is quaint & quirky. It's good but not luxurious. For the money you could probably find comparable accommodation elsewhere in the city.
reviews.title: Good..... but not quite luxury

reviews.text: What I would recommend is the canal trip with the hotel's own small boat. It's pricier than the standard tour boats but you travel on a 100 year old (refurbished) boat, with excellent & informative information from the skipper, with alcoholic drinks whenever you wish, a must for seeing some of the canals the larger boats cannot access.
reviews.title: Don't expect grandiose

reviews.text: For 300 Euro a nite, this hotel was incomparable to our other hotel stay in Amsterdam. On the first day, two hours after we had checked in, we were awoken from our nap. The guy staying above our room was making so much noise and dropping things, heavy footsteps, etc. We complained to the front desk to please move us to another room. They said they would call the person staying above our room to quiet down. I said it was not his fault that we could hear everything. On our floor and upstairs, there were wooden floors with no area rugs or carpet. We stayed there two nights and couldn't wait to get out of there. We were disappointed that they did not try to accomodate us with our special request. I don't think they are a 5 star hotel as quoted. When we were checking out, we mentioned about it to another front desk person and she apologized. We suggested they lay carpets or rugs to prevent the noise. Also complained that we did not get proper rest because of the noise.

reviews.text: We stayed over the first weekend of March and I regret that this will be our last stay at this once 5 star hotel. We have had many a happy stay, but I have seen a gradual deterioration in the standards over the past 9 years. I understand that over a period of 9 years I can not expect the accommodation to not show wear and tear, however that would be acceptable if the efforts on general house keeping where maintained.

I hope that the Luxury Collection will be addressing this hotel as a matter of urgency, and polish their service to when we first visited. Beware this hotel is now overpriced dirty and not giving a 5star service. Come on Pulitzer MAKE THE EFFORT!

reviews.text: I have just returned from another stay at the Pulitzer Hotel in Amsterdam and to my mind, you cannot stay in a better hotel. I have stayed at some of the best hotels in Europe and nothing compares with the Pulitzer in Amsterdam – it is like coming home. The staff are professional and yet always welcoming – they make you feel that nothing is too much trouble. Some years ago I bought two garden tables and without asking the tables were bundled up securely to protect them from the flight home. They arrived home without a scratch! The Service in the Restaurant is excellent and the food imaginative and delicious. I have eaten at other 'best' hotels in Amsterdam but there is something about the Pulitzer that makes it stand apart from the rest. The rooms are very well decorated and maintained to a high standard. The canal rooms are light and airy and have magnificent marble bathrooms. As the hotel is built within a number of canal houses, finding ones way around can be daunting for the faint-hearted, but all corridors lead to the well-designed enclosed passageway across the central garden courtyard. Check-in and check-out couldn’t be easier and the staff at the reception are charming, efficient and knowledgeable. I shall be returning later on this year, as it is the only place to stay when in Amsterdam.
reviews.title: Probably the best hotel in Amsterdam

reviews.text: As someone that travels quite a bit and is very loyal to the SPG program, in Amsterdam there are really only two choices for us. The Sheraton Amsterdam by the Airport, or the Hotel Pulitzer. I've been to the Sheraton before and it has been a good experience there, and this time I wanted to try something a bit different and more centrally located to the city itself.
reviews.title: The most unique hotel!

reviews.text: First off, when you get to Amsterdam Central definitely ask someone where the hotel is. It's in a bit of a discrete location between canals so it can be hard to find. Fortunately, Amsterdam has some of the most friendly people on the planet so they're always happy to help you.
reviews.title: Exceptional service in an interesting hotel!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Once you get to the hotel, you can't help but notice the unique appearance. Is this really one large hotel connected by canal houses? You better believe it! The lobby itself is nice and quiet, I was greeted by a very friendly receptionist that acknowledged my status with the SPG program and then informed me that I had been upgraded to one of their Luxury Suites! It had been a stressful day of travel so to hear this was very positive. I was taken up to my room which was on the 5th floor, but was really the 3rd floor. And it was the only room on that floor. Confused yet? This is one of the very unique things about this hotel. It's very easy to get lost, but you just have to pay attention to the signs. There are over 200 rooms and it's all connected by 20+ canal houses. I've never seen anything like this before, and that's a great thing.
